title: The Voluntary Disconnect
outcome: Citizens are given a choice—remain in a limited BCI, or “disconnect” and join analog-only communities. Marked by chalk circles, analog neighborhoods thrive on self-organization. Tensions and debates rise, but two systems operate in a fragile, uneasy peace—Halden’s legacy becomes coexistence, not collapse.

events.description: Following citywide debates, Oksana Lintz offers citizens a public choice: continue under a pared-down BCI, or disconnect completely and use only analog, non-digital services.
Thousands opt to disconnect, marking doors and streets with chalk circles. Volunteer groups rapidly organize local resources, relying on neighbor cooperation and direct barter.
Tensions flare as resource flows shift—some BCI-dependent neighborhoods report shortages, while analog zones thrive. Heated debates play out in both official forums and public squares.
Council tries to mediate, proposing resource-sharing between disconnected and BCI neighborhoods. Both sides set terms, resulting in a tense but lasting compromise.

Public displays now feature Halden’s early writings on freedom of choice. Halden’s legacy is reinterpreted: instead of a single unified system, Stenograd moves forward with two parallel societies living side by side.
